solution.text:
In similar triangles all the angles are equal
>i.e., \(\angle A = \angle A'\)
>i.e., \(\angle B = \angle B'\)
>i.e., \(\angle C = \angle C'\)
Hence, \(\angle A\over \angle A'\) = \(\angle B\over \angle B'\)
Similarly, In similar triangles ratios of sides are equal
\(BC\over B'C'\) = \(AB\over A'B'\)
But not necessarily sides are equal

content.text: For two similar triangle ABC and A'B'C', Which of the following statements are true?
